Venezia is not the right town to go to by car (many residents do not even own one!) so i think train is a better option. There's a high speed line connecting Milano and Venezia.
Train.and you CAN stop in Lake Garda (Desenzano) and Verona.(train station is about 15 minutes from the center)
Take the train. No cars in Venice
Train would be easiest.

Train for sure.....really
easy...direct trip, 2.5 hours, goes right to the Grand Canal. I booked all my train trips on Trainline.
Train
Venice Group Services is a private transfer company. They are great and reliable!!
Train

I would take the train....as with driving you have the rental plus parking fees... more convenient and probably a lot cheaper....🙃

text:
Good evening!
This is a different type of question than i have seen here, but I need some advice or suggestions!
We are going on a Mediterranean cruise in a couple of weeks. One of the days will be spent inआणखी florence.
I am trying to decide what to do while there. Out of these two options… what would you recommend?
An 8 hour tour “ The Jewels of Cinque Terre” or the hop on, hop off bus?

comments.comment_text: Firenze does not have a port. I guess your cruise will stop in either La Spezia or Livorno. If the stop is La Spezia, then go to Cinque Terre. If your stop is Livorno, then go to Firenze. (Choice by shortest path, so you don't waste time and make the most of your few hours here!).

We just did this tour two weeks ago. It’s a large boat/ferry that drives past all 5 towns and you stop at 3 of them and get some free time to explore on your own. The lunch was awful but the guide and towns were wonderful. It was nice to see all of the areas and get pictures from the water
Walk around Florence is so scenic

text:
Planning a trip to Italy next sept. Hiking the Dolomites for sure. Then thinking Amalfi Coast and/or Cinque Terra? We love hiking, walking and nature but not into museums. are these 2 spots too similar for just exploring???
Also Matera a possibility 🤷‍♀️ any advise??? And maybe Venice
Thanks!!!!

comments.comment_text: Cinque Terre over Amalfi anyday
Would you not consider the dolomites then lake Garda and on to cinque terra? All three areas are excellent for walking
You like nature? Discover Abruzzo region!!!!! You won't be disappointed at all!!!!!

Not similar at all. Both areas have good hiking, although Ligurian Coast around Portofino and Santa Margarita is great hiking. You tube has some videos of some tricky trails. You won’t be disappointed. Dolomites are awe inspiring. Wish I was younger again.
The Dolomites and Amalfi are very far apart. I would stay in Northern Italy (Dolomites + Liguria) A plethora of amazing hikes + stunning views and less touristy than Amalfi.
It will take a whole day to get from the Dolomites to amalfi
You’ll love both
Yes!

text:
Hello everyone! Looking for recommendations
for NON TOURISTY food places in all of Amalfi Coast/ Capri. Authentic. Delicious.
Thanks so much!

comments.comment_text: Ravello is Beautiful! Quieter than most places in the Amalfi
Lara Jupp

So I’ve been here for over 30 days traveling all over Italy. I posed the same questions in various forums and of course everyone has their favorite. With all the recommendations
, I looked for a consensus on particular restaurants and ￼wrote those down, and here is what I learned. Restaurants have bad days. There were several restaurants that were highly recommended by a majority only for it to be not so great, It could be a server who has a bad attitude or the chef or main cook is off that day or maybe I ordered the wrong item. Honestly, it was like a 50-50 split based on the recommendations
. Conclusion, recommendations
are good including the review-based apps, one of the things that I do that kind of narrows down the possibility of a bad meal or experience is I usually go to these review apps, click on the latest reviews and look for the last 5 to 10 reviews to see if I notice a negative trend , if you see things mentioned like bad attitude, bad service, the food was just OK I would eliminate those. I did have a lot of luck of just walking down side streets, finding a hole in the wall and having a delicious meal and then recommending that same restaurant to friends for them to have a bad meal lol! Anyhow, that’s my two cents. Enjoy yourself!
￼
Book a food tour in Sorrento, they take you to all the authentic places.
Go where locals go .cheaper also
Unfortunately there is nothing non touristy about the Amalfi coast and most definitely not about Capri. Capri is like a theme park

Le tre sorelle Positano, just on the beach.it s a family run restaurant.Exce
llent food and I am Italian!
Of course the Amalfi coast or Capri are very touristic, especially this time of the year

My advice would be to stay away from restaurants on the main strip or in the main square. Try a trattoria (smaller cafe style restaurants) down a side alley. These are less visited by tourists, less expensive, and a more authentic Italian experience. In these places do not expect them to speak to you in English. Learn some Italian phrases. There is so much free resource on the internet that there is no excuse not being able to speak some Italian. Learn to say can I have a table for 2. Where is the bathroom. Can I have the bill please. Can I have another (glass of wine). A little Italian goes a long way. Trust me. Also use the Google translate camera app to translate the menu into English.
Lastly, avoid any restaurant that has pictures of the food outside the restaurant and or on the menu.
Avoid Amalfi. It’s so touristy. Go to Sorrento. See Positano from the sea.
Avoid Capri as it’s very expensive and touristy. Visit Ischia instead.
Minori

I'm from the area.

In Amalfi "trattoria da Gemma"
In Capri "da Giorgio al cucciolo"
Minori is probably the least non touristy. Quaint, not over crowded & wonderful restaurants. Easy ferry access too. No steps.
Had a wonderful , unforgettable experience in Sorento, up on the stairs, small street to the right from the central street of the market. Have been there few years ago, hope it still exists.

https://
www.casamele.com
/

In Positano, not touristy but off the charts delicious!

We’ve been 4 times and it keeps getting better!

They are open for dinner & also have daytime cooking classes
Everyone’s opinion on food is different, but look for those neat little small tucked away places !
Maria Grazia and Ristorante del bona del capo had amazing food

looking for 'non-toursity' food...in the most touristy places in the country. Want authentic? I'd go to a town you've never heard of - one that doesn't get tourists. You'll probably save half your money, have a great meal, meet real Italians, and help a restaurant that needs the business.
Le grottelle in Capri. I’m still dreaming with their pasta con polpo. It was their special that day and I understand they are family owned.
Azzuro in Sorrento not strictly Amalfi Costa but most restaurants in Procida
Go 10 blocks away from the tourist area.
Quanto Basto Sorrento
We found the small outside tables on the water in Sorrento were very good. It is a walk down and then back up. If you can do it, it's with it.

Hopefully you will get Sonja as server. Wonderful time
Capri

Hotel Bonadies in RAVELLO
Glorious rooftop restaurant. Second to few view. Exceptional traditional fare.

text: Hello everyone. Looking at going to Lido Di Jeslo, in May 2024.....recommendations for hotels. TIA 😊

comments.comment_text: Definitely Principe Palace on the piazza Mazzini. We have stayed a couple of times and it seems like many people return year after year. Some for over 20 years !The location is fantastic , cross the Piazza, two minutes down the street, and you’re at the beach, they have all their own sun lounges on a section of the beach that you don’t have to pay for. The food is amazing. We are vegan and the chef cooked us, fresh delicious, amazing food every evening. Some of the bathrooms in the rooms could do with a little update but I they everything you need and the rooms are cleaned and the sheets and towels are changed every single day. text:
Hi!
We are at Amalfi and trying to book a private boat tour for Amalfi coast.
Any suggestions? TIA!!

We are planning a delayed honeymoon to Italy in November. Can anyone that has traveled during this time please let me know what you brought to wear? I was thinking a peacoat and sweaters. I want to be warm but don’t want to overdress. Is it too cold for long sleeved dresses and a coat?

I have also included our current itinerary below.
What wouldआणखी you recommend based on our current selections?? I’ve been dying to go to Amalfi Coast but I heard it’s pretty much shut down during this time of year but would still love to go if it’s worth it. Venice is our backup.

Rome - 2 days
Florence - 2 days
Amalfi coast OR Venice - 2 days

What are our best options for migrating between locations? Are there trains going to and from each destination? If you booked a separate transfer as well, do you have a recommendation on a company to go with?

Recommendations on restaurants, tours, classes and sights also welcome💜💜

The rest of our trip will most likely be in Switzerland or Hungary.

comments.comment_text: When you say 2 days so you means 2 nights?

Forget Amalfi, not worth it and not enough time, you barely have enough time as it is. Do Rome, Florence and Venice ... trains are best weather should be mild to cool, could get cold at night. Light layers are best and have an umbrella..... waterproof your shoes.
I went to Venice in December and didn't need a coat just wore a jumper dress

I'd stay North and miss Amalfi. You can use Trainline App or website to book trains easily. Some very fast trains are worth looking at, standard and first/business class depending on budget unless you like checking the scenery. Temperatures for different times of year in the different cities you visit can be checked via Google or a decent weather App. North will be colder than South but TBH hard to predict these days with climate change. Essentially, pack light but for variable weather, so low-weight layers and have a way of covering say legs and arms (tights and sweater maybe) for cold days. Always worth trying to stay carry-on bags only to cancel the risks of lost bags - particularly painful if you are also moving from city to city. Also, it helps to book an AirBnB or similar with a washing machine to minimise the need for overpacking and ease of getting on and off flights and trains and taxis and such.
High risk of aqua Alta in Venice in November, just be aware

Either Venice or Amalfi Coast, been to both in the winter. Bother are beautiful, nothing is shut down as Christmas shopping for shops is still needed. As far as comparing, you can't they are both magnificent, and one of a kind. As far as less time traveling, Doing, Rome, Florence and Venice makes more sense. Personally, with that short of time, I'd do Rome 4 days, Florence or Venice 2.
Are you going to northern italy or southern Italy. It's a huge difference

Loved a long extended November trip in Rome. A few days of rain…no problem. Will take that over heat and crowds. Amalfi Coast shuts down at end of October. Consider Florence over Rome and do Tuscany and day trip to Cinque Terre. Venice is magical for a Honeymoon spot. Have visited in both October and February.
It will be in the 60-70 degree range in the south - we have done Rome and the southern coast at Christmas and I describe it as “flip flop and sweater weather”😊
Have been told Cinque Terre is pretty much closed by that time of the year.

We usually spend two months that ends the second week of November. It’s still fairly warm around that time. Only once have we been cold and that was one short night in Milan. Seldom have I had to wear anything more than jeans and a sweater if it’s a cooler day. And in 2019 I never even wore my slacks and long sleeve shirts. I wore shorts and tops right up to the day we left.
Amalfi coast is pretty much shut down by November

I visited Italy in the second half of November and traveled from Rome to Venice, Bologna, Florence then back to Rome. It was cold for me (I'm usually cold 😀) and it rained/
drizzled some of the time. I wore mostly sweaters, peacoats, scarves, jeans/corduroy pants and sometimes a hat.

text: Looking for recommendations on what area to stay in Rome?I’ll be there 6 nights, looking for more local stuff .. neighborhoods, restaurants, cafes and such . I can travel to the big tourist attractions. Thank you !!!
Can someone please explain travel insurance? How do I get it when booking everything without travel agent ? What should I have covered ?

comments.comment_text: Just go n to the net and do a search for travel insurance. Its not expensive. You can insure for anything. Cancellation of holiday .... loss of luggage etc. But most importantly insurance for accident and illhealth. Should yiu find yourself in hospital abroad you want insurance to cover those costs!

I Check on line for quotes, mainly with larger companies that I know and trust.
Check the fine print, like unlimited medical, total covered for, lost luggage, exclusions for pre-existing medical conditions, I pay extra to be covered. Hire cars , sports etc. Just do a lot of research, even very expensive ones can cover very little.
Some credit cards offer free travel insurance, if whole trip booked on them. Can be high excess, or age restrictions.
Go to Allianz web site to book. They're excellent and I always use them when I travel anywhere

Squaremouth.com
. You can side by side compare many policies and pick the one that best meets your needs and pricepoint.

There are many to choose from but this is the one that I went with for me self and family.

https://
www.imglobal.com
/
You can buy through Triple A.

You go about it like everything else you do when planning a trip. Do the research, and act accordingly. Go online and organise a quote with at least a couple of companies. Everyone’s quote will be different in accordance to your age, health cover requirements , things you want covered , and activities you want to do in your chosen destination. It’s super easy. It’s not cheap, but it definitely gives you some peace of mind. Hopefully you won’t need to use it.

Google travel insurance, the type country leaving and countries going, when leaving and day arriving back,the choose the best one for the price. Unlimited medical is a must and Unlimited cancellation plus covid cover very simple. Most important have it in place the day you start booking everything
Call Allianz & get an annual policy if you travel often.
We will only use Alianz based on experience . Look on line and chose what best suits you but make sure you take medical evacuation
Some debit cards include travel insurance. See what your bank has to offer. What country do you live in?
I’m an agent and would be happy to book it for you.

text: Could I please have some recommendations for a nice restaurant in Sorrento, Italy

comments.comment_text: Tasso
IL BUCO

Small and casual but very good food and we went no problem with a reservation - Piennolo Land Food. We also ate at semola one night when we were tired…it was right next to our hotel. It’s basically just pasta but done very well. Enjoyed it a lot

Restorante Zi Ntonio and Trattoria Antica

Depends on what you call nice. My favourite restaurant in Sorrento was not a fancy place. It's called La Cantinaccia del Popolo. Look at the comments on TripAdvisor. You cannot book ahead, you have to go there and wait for a table suitable for the size of your party. If you don't want to wait too long, go at 6.30pm and you should be one of the first to be seated when they open at 7pm. Locals eat there, it's got a small but perfectly formed menu, great service and 3 types of complimentary limoncello on offer after you've eaten. And it was the cheapest meal we had by far.

Fauno Bar in Piazza Tasso is also quite nice. Not anything too exciting, but lovely all the same, with great service and a great place to people watch.

text:
Just wondering if it’s easier and more economical to purchase a hair straightener with - 230 V in Rome ( or anywhere else in Italy as we are touring around).

I was confused thinking I could still use our Canadian hair straightener over there with some sort of adapter but I was mistaken.

Any tips where I could purchase it in Rome and approximate cost so I know I’m not being gouged .
TIA 🇮🇹

comments.comment_text:
Specialised department stores: Media World, Trony, Euronics, ...
Be aware that temperature settings will be in Celsius degrees
I found a dual voltage one here (USA) that took abroad. Read the labels carefully. It was not a expensive. Also check Amazon.
I’d purchase a dual voltage off Amazon. I’d rather do that then search for one on vacation.
My CHI brand irons are dual voltage. I thought they all were nowadays. Check on the power supply.

Tool Science makes a good flat iron for about $50, dual voltage, available on Amazon. Use with regular adapter (American to European). Get before you go, be ready to roll upon arrival, don't waste time shopping for a flat iron.
I actually bought a nice one in Ireland some years back for about $25. It was in one of their pharmacy/drug stores. I knew it would be completely safe for future trips.
Or bring converter to use current one
Buy dual voltage in states that way you can use it back home as well. Just be sure to switch it back when you return.
€20 at a drug store in Rome.

I bought a converter and mine still fried!! Don’t risk it if you have a good/expensive straightener. Ended up buying one in a drugstore (in Germany, but I know they’re available most places!! Cheaper than US too).
I’m in Italy right now now and have been using my straightener with an adapter. So far so good
Michael Strijder see i should just leave mine at home......
I believe the cheaper straightners like Target or Kmart work not ghd ones🙃

I bought a dual voltage one on Amazon before our trip. I used it once the whole time since with the extreme heat/humidity, I had to tie my hair up constantly, and couldn't bother with how it looked lol
I purchased a curling iron in a pharmacy in Rome. It was €16 and honestly it works better than any of my American ones lol.
Erika your exact question. Read comments.

text:
Hello I’m new here. Planning to surprise my mom with a trip to Italy in 2024. She’s in her 70’s so mobility is a bit of a concern for us, as she can’t walk very far in 1 shot.

I have no idea where to begin planning this bucket list trip for her. Shes waited her whole life to go. She’d love to see Rome and the Vatican and I want to see Venice andआणखी maybe see Naples since that where her grandparents were born.

I’d like to know when the best time of year to go would be and if there are tours that cater to seniors by supplying scooters or something she can get around in.

comments.comment_text: I'd go October to have less heat and crowds. I'd do less but use 'honest' pay via app taxis to get around. I'd focus on her interests. Stay as much as reasonable in one place to avoid the hassle of packing and unpacking. I would definitely get her views on interests and such rather than guess. The fast train to naples is a good option if you want to stay there 2 or 3 days.

I go to Italy twice a year and I’m taking a friend in October, nice (usually) I have been going for 16 years to Italy so what I would do arrive in Rome have a few days (jet lag) I’m from Australia so it’s 23hours so I usually have 3 days, train to Naples (fast train I use Italo company ask for seniors discount and not much difference in 1st and economy (from memory, I was there in February). Stay , I’m sure you will have family to sort out that for you. Then I would take the fast train to Florence or go straight to Venice. I’m 72yrs old and the thing I tell everyone try and get really fit then have the best walking shoes ( wear them in) cross body bag with a few zips & don’t take the world . I have a backpack, cross body bag and cabin size case. 🌻

What a lovely thing to do! 😊 Look at golf cart tours and I have read they do a special tour at the Vatican on train or something, search that? Or maybe someone has done that and will share their info. Enjoy.

I believe you can rent scooters in Rome. There is also the golf cart tour of Rome, that you and your mother might like. If you take any trains, check out Saler blue as they offer support for those with mobility issues. They will take you to your train and you can buy your ticket through them. They are located in the main train stations.
What are beautiful place to visit with mom. Have fun and know that you’ll need new Visas starting in 2024.

Not sure what your budget is private drivers tours might be the way to go. Definitely golf cart tours I have booked in Rome & Florence &go in late October less crowds warm but not hot. I'm sure she will be happy to be there & whatever you manage to see will be perfect in her eyes❤️

Sept/Oct/Apr/
May are probably good times in order to avoid excessive heat and craziness of tourists.

Definitely google ‘tours of Rome for seniors’ or tours of ‘’Vatican’, Venice’, ‘’Naples’ or ‘any￼where else you’d like to go’ for seniors.

Keep in mind these tours might not be ‘your’ ideal but I promise you they’ll be worth it if your mom feels loved.

I’ve been traveling 50+ years (since before my 20’s). Many different kinds of trips, a few different travel partners ….

Now, as I approach 70 myself and reflect on my own travels, the trips I took with my mom
during HER 70’s are always the first ones to come to mind. I would not trade one minute of those memories for anything else ….

I was there last year at 80. I rented a place in Rome and stayed nearly a month. I was in Monti district close to all kinds of transport. I walked to the Colosseum and to wonderful churches, some very old and three of the major basilicas including the glorious Santa Maria Maggiore. I walked to Termini station. I took the metro to other places . Everyone was friendly and helpful. My cane kept me steady on the sometimes rough surfaces.

You could easily take fast trains to Naples, Venice and Rome.

Keep luggage really minimal so you can lift it onto trains.

Have fun.
October for sure, golf cart tours

Venice may be a challenge due to the stairs up and down for the multitude of bridges. Be sure wherever you stay has an elevator and that it goes to all floors. There are a lot of buildings without them. Also, the ground floor is zero. The first floor is one story up. Read the reviews diligently so you don’t get an unpleasant surprise. Even with all this diligence, we still ended up in a 3rd floor walk up in Venice because they “upgraded” us. We had originally planned on only having to climb up one story.
Hope you have a wonderful time!

Everyone here makes a good point! I’ve been traveling to Rome on those overnight flights from CA and the east coast for years, and I have had success with the both the hit-the-ground-
running / early dinner / early-ish bedtime approach as well as the afternoon-nap / early evening stroll / normal Roman dinner time approach. It also depends on how much time you will have in Rome overall, which kind of dictates how okay you are going to feel about not having something in place that first day. I personally think golf cart tours in Rome or anywhere are a really good way to get an overview and orientation without having to think about anything or deal with reading a map. Anyway you slice it, you *will* be tired that first day and the less you have to get your brain in gear to be in charge of leading the family around, the better it will be! My advice is to let someone else take the wheel—book the golf cart tour for 7:30 and grab a nap and shower at the hotel in the blazing hot afternoon. Gives you some wiggle room too vs the 3pm in case the flight is delayed. I would definitely make sure the tour can include some stops for pizza and gelato as we all know keeping the kids (and yourselves) fed will be key to everyone’s success! Then, to bed, and you’ll be in good shape adjusting to the time change. The golf cart tours also cover a lot more ground than the typical radius of what you can realistically explore on foot, such as the Aventine keyhole, the big fountain on the Janiculum, etc. Hope this helps!

Having just finished our Rome and Greece trip(we started at Chicago), I enjoyed the travel day without excursions. Everyone is tired. We were a 7 hour change and it was 7:30 AM in Rome when we landed. I traveled with 17 and 20 year old. We looked around when we first got there and relaxed in the afternoon and dinner and bed. Then ready to go the next day. I think a tour that day would have ruined our 2 week trip with that packed in the beginning
We hit the ground running. A golf cart tour is really nice, you get to see so much. Have fun

I'm planning a trip in spring (no kids 3 senior ladies)but thought we would do golf cart tour arrival date too.Seems logical and gives you a good overview ,I think kids would enjoy it and keep them interested for awhile without having to completely exhaust them with walking after the flight...just an opinion
I’d be cautious about a 3.00 booking. Any delays and you’ll miss it.
I personally never book anything for the day of arrival. There are too many variables, late flights, baggage issues etc. That way if you are a few hours late it’s no big deal
Do it! We arrived in Heathrow at noon and had a layover/flight to Rome, getting us to Rome at 9:00 pm. We went out to dinner. We slept about 2 hours on the overnight flight. It’ll be great!
We did a golf cart tour at 2pm last week. It was a great way to beat the heat with some shade and the breeze from the cart. Highly recommend!
Do it, do the later one though in the evening, evenings are so much nicer than the heat of the day
I would do the later. Stay up late and sleep in. Get rid of the jet leg.
You will be exhausted, specially traveling with kiddos.

text: I leave for my trip on Sunday!!! My husband only wanted 1 night in Florence and I’m struggling with planning the city with so little time. Our train from Venice gets us to Florence around 11am and we leave at 11am the following day. We are staying just outside the city. What is best to experience in my 24 hours??

comments.comment_text:
With such an inadequate time in Florence why would you stay outside the city? Staying in the center would at at least have allowed you to maximize your time there by letting you get a better feel for this amazing place. Waking up early to discover Florence during her morning hush is a real treat. Watching a sunset from the Piazalle Michelangelo and then wandering the night time streets is also a great experience. Since you’ve chosen to stay in a place that might preclude these wonderfully charming experiences & on top of that only scheduled a single day there I question how much you’ll gain by going.

You’ll be rushing around too
much during your single day trying to include too much in too
few hours to really enjoy anything. With such a short time there I question if you’ll be able to absorb even the slightest bit of the unique charm and atmosphere of one of the best cities in Italy. Florence is capable of seeping into your soul & enriching you. But you have to give it half a chance to do so.

It’s too late now to rethink your planned itinerary. So at this point you’ll just have to live with the plans you’ve already made. No one can do everything on any one trip, so on this trip all you’ll get is a glimpse of Florence. Look at what Florence has to offer and try to do the one or two things that most appeal to you. Then move on to your next destination

Since your husband insisted on one day there you should have him plan out the day. Take the stress off yourself and let him deal with this decision he made.
One day is better than nothing. Book a day tour to take in all the main sites and no need to listen to the negative people on here.
If at all possible, at least change your reservation to something in town. That way, you can see everything on foot and go to your room to take a breather now and then.

You can go all the main sights in that time you maybe just won’t be able to go in to museums etc , it’s quite a small town so walkable
Go and see the Duomo, pointe vecchio , the view from piazzle Michelangelo
Then go to the wine window down borgo san frediano
Then maybe boboli gardens?
Walk the city. Relax, enjoy.

Just make the most of your time! 24 hrs is better than nothing. Way to compromise with your husband. 😊
Book Accademia to see the David upon arrival. Then, visit the Duomo and mercato centrale and ponte vecchio.
Also might want to check out tours on Airbnb experiences.
Duomo and David at Accademia. Short walk in between. Otherwise walking and enjoy the city.
If you only have 1 day do the tourist bus

Wow. Where to start? I’m torn between saying that you should skip Florence altogether or try to meet the challenge. But here goes. First, staying outside of town is a mistake. Getting there and returning to town will eat up time. And you can’t enjoy the night. Florence is a museum and church city. Do you care about these things? Do you care about the Renaissance? If yes, do the Academia/
Uffici/Duomo Museum group with walks through town. If you don’t care about this stuff, stay outside: climb the campanile, go to P. Michelangelo, eat big meals, cycle down the river. All you’re gonna get is a taste. Make it a good one.
Ugh. Did you reserve David or Uffizi Tix? If not, go to the Duomo and Ponte Vecchio.

We spent a day in Florence now it was busy but we did the cathedral and dome. Went to see the bridge with the shops in and went to the square with fake David and Santa Croce. We did want to go and see the real David but you really need to book to go there. Then we walked around the food market before getting the train back to Lucca.

We are thinking of going back soon to see Florence again. But it just wonder around the streets and actually go over the other side of the bridge with the shops on it. We just didn’t have time the first time around. We did what we could when we where there.
What about booking a tour of the city. They will bring you to the must sees.
See David and walk around, get lost, pop into the Duomo

If I only had one day I'd start at the Central Market, have lunch and walk around, pre book skip the line tickets to the Accademia Gallery early afternoon and see David, leave there and walk to the Doumo because it's AMAZING (even if you only see the outside) , head to Piazza della Signoria for a good look around (maybe get a gelato) and most certainly end the day at Piazza Michelangelo for the amazing sunset. I'd eat dinner in Oltramo because we found better food and prices in that neighborhood.
Try World Trail scavenger hunt, takes you round all places of historic and cultural significance whilst informing you on the way and you also pass many eateries and drinking poo spots.
Rule of thumb - always do two nights in every place - otherwise you are ‘out on the street’ at 10 am every time - with luggage if you cannot store them - no fun

First of all, you're outside of the city, so you're gonna start at one p m. Go to viator and catch the afternoon no line viewing of david and the Cathedral.
After that walk the center city and go to the ponta vecchio. Then go have a great dinner . you can do with just about every restaurant. Then get ready to leave the city.

In one day i would see the Accademia, lunch at All'Antico Vinaio , walk to ponte Vecchio, eat in Santo Spirito ( Gusto pizza) then go watch the sunset at piazza Michaelangelo while drinking a Prosseco ! 😉😍

Take the Hip-Hop bus. Stop at Piazzale MichelAngelo and see the whole city from there. A walk at the banks of Arno, Ponte Vecchio and there you are in Piazza della Signoria. Take a coffee in Piazza della Rpepubblica, in cafe Gilli, maybe, one of the oldest in Europe. If you are not an art scholar why spend half a day to admire Davide in Galleria? So many copies of it around the city, you can not tell the difference. You are visiting a city, you don't take exams. Enough with Florence and its fallacies.

I've seen some clever plans in the comments. My two cents would be to find a place to store your luggage for the day upon arrival. Then head to lunch at the San Lorenzo market. If you can, find a bike tour that will take you to the main sights. Then walk, walk, walk as much as you can to get a feel for the incredible vibe of the city. I have been to Florence so many times and I still have not been to either the Uffizi or the Academia 😬 because whenever I get to Florence, I just want to explore the city and not be in a museum all day. One day, I will do it though. If you have a chance to get into one of the main churches (Duomo, Santa Croce or Santa Maria Novella), go for it... they're as beautiful inside as they are outside. Then pick up your luggage and head up to piazza Michelangelo at sunset before checking into your hotel. And make sure to have a good ice cream before you leave.

Go see the Duomo, have a gelato then go to the Piazza Michelangelo, see the replica of David and take a panorama picture of Florence. Walk thru Pompei in sweltering heat, go home and watch "The Medici" series on Netflix and see why you should have visited Florence. Hopefully your husband will watch tv. Speaking of that, I'd watch a 15 minute YouTube on Pompei, and if I couldn't stay in Florence, I'd go to the springs in Saturnia instead!

I was in Florence 2 days and I wish I would have stayed at least 3 😩 not enough time for such a beautiful city

With such limited time I would store my luggage at the train station and buy skip the line or a Florence Pass - with timed entries- pick your bags up after a day of touring and then check into the hotel.
One night doesn’t even give you one full day. Two nights gives you only one day. I’m speaking from experience. Your minimum should be three full days, which means four nights.

"Leave your husband" (even though obviously in jest) & "spend more time" & "change your accomdations" aren't helpful for someone who is leaving in 2 days & plans are set. Just answer the question of how one might best spend 8 hrs in the city if that is all the time they have this trip.
In such a beautiful city put YOUR happiness first. Being a wife and mother many sacrifices made, for this one fill your cup first and you’ll be happy you did.
Segway tour and cooking class

Book direct for David with a set time .

If you want U can book direct for the uffuzi gallery u can also add in - pitti palace and boboli gardens as they have a deal for the 3 together. Or separate . Or skip it .

walk- eat shop .
I'd do the Jop on, Hop off bus
Ditch the husband and stay longer 😂
For sure go see the sunset
This is difficult to get much in if you are staying outside city. Try to book a walking tour to do.
Palazzo Pitti and Giardino di Boboli.
Hirer Maria through your local tour guide. Expensive but you’ll get to see all the highlights of Florence in 6-7hrs. She was a life savor for us.

After 1 day in Florence, your husband should just go, anywhere, and you should remain in Florence ( preferably for a week)
There might be something wrong with your husband if he thinks one day in Florence is enough. It’s not.
How long have you had him ??

Honestly, I would just walk around the central part of Florence and take it all in. Include the Duomo, the Ponte Vecchio, the Uffizzi, all easily walkable from the train station. Stay very near the station.

Well I certainly wouldn't let my husband make all the vacation decisions.
Compromise .... Tell him you want to stay for a week and then compromise to 3 or 4 days.
Golf cart tour - you'll hit all the big things in just about 2 hours and then you can have the rest of the time to wander wherever you like.
Duomo, Accademia and Ponte Vecchio.
You need more than 24 hours in one of the most beautiful and important Italian cities.
We did a golf cart tour and that was a great way to see the city!
Why donu need to listen your housband😵‍💫 just stay longer ,one day even one week is not enought 🤷‍♀️

#1 thing to do is get skip the line tickets for the Accademia to see The David. Schedule the rest of your time around that, including taking a walking tour of some sort or just wander with a good map to hit some of the highlights of interest to you. Rick Steves guide has good info/maps. Finally, schedule a food tour for the evening where you'll get a chance to taste a variety of local specialties from several different places (rather than just one restaurant) and get a bit more on the history and culture of the city along the way. You'll be amazed at what you can fit into 24 hours with some good planning. Have fun!
1 day is not enough
You will regret if you miss Accademia Gallery of Florence (Galleria dell'Accademia di Firenze)..
Wait, husbands can do that?? ((Flips thru Husband Manual))
My favourite was seeing David, but we ￼ bought our tickets months ahead of time. The line was so long!!!!

With so many people visiting and with the heat you might be ready to move on after 24 hrs.
I would just get the ticket for the Galleria, visit Ponte Vecchio, do a walking tour and enjoy a fantastic gelato
Just walk around and enjoy your day…:))
One week in Florence is not enough. Can you move days from other towns. If your going to Venice for more then two days move some from there.
Nothing, don’t schedule a thing. Walk and explore on your own for the short time you have.
IMO you don’t want to miss The David.
It will be extremely crowded and the lines yesterday around the Duomo where ridiculous. Get up at 6am and enjoy the city before the masses get up….

Florence has been my favourite city by far in all of Italy!! Book visits to galleries asap if you’re only here for a day as they sell out quite quickly! You must go to the gallery which the statue of David and the Uffizzi gallery! Piazzale Michelangelo for sunset and just get lost in the city 🤍 I didn’t find the inside of the cathedral that amazing (I wouldnt of waited 1.5 hours in line if I had known) but found the outside breathtaking! Walking tour definitely if you’re only here for 24 hours!

text: We are going to Italy in January. Looking at visiting (coming from Switzerland) Milan, Portifino, Venice and fly out of Rome. Is 7days enough? And how is best to navigate in order to visit each? TIA (btw this group is amazing)

comments.comment_text: 7 days will never be enough

If it were me, I’d spend the entire week in Rome. Of course everybody travels for different reasons. I found out this summer that, if you’re not careful, you can lose an awful lot of time just going from one place to another. I had to switch apartments in Genoa this summer. Even though the apartments were only a few blocks from each other, because of check in/out times, I lost a good 5 hours that day.

text:
Hi there! We are a party of 8 (4 of them are kids) going to Florence, Venice and Rome at the end of November over thanksgiving break! We have 8 days to see these towns after removing travel days.

What are the main things to see?
Any cooking classes you recommend ?
Or fun things to do with kids ages 10-15?
Hotel and restaurants you love?

THANK YOU!!!!

comments.comment_text: Oh boy! There is so much to do in just one of those places! I highly recommend the Vatican Museum, the Trevi Fountain, the Coloseum, Spanish Steps, lots of food, wine and gelato in Rome! Thats just the tip of the iceberg. Look for a City Pass, sometimes you can skip the lines w those. We used them this year in Ireland and Germany.
I just got back a few weeks ago. You will love it!!
Ahhhhh…you convinced Mike! I’m jealous. 😉

text:
I’m just headed home from my Italy/Switzerland vacation. We did 2 nights Sorrento, 3 nights Rome, 3 nights Florence, 2 nights Venice. For everyone who posts itineraries and is told to eliminate a destination because “it’s too much,” I can say I am very happy with how my trip went. You do not waste an entire day traveling, as so many say. The regional trains get you between the cities in 1-2 hours. We would drop our luggage off as soon as we got to town and begin exploring.
I’m definitely not saying we weren’t busy, but that’s how we travel.

comments.comment_text: I totally agree, we hit the ground running, didn't waste a minute. It was GREAT!!!
Thank you for your post. I think that by travelling you waste time, so why not do 2-3 nights in one place. I am going with three other people and I am p,and I g the itinerary. I 109% agree with you.
Can't wait to be back!
Agreed. Sometimes I even add an extra night on the front-end and arrange an early check-in. Train travel days are not wasted! Just a few hours to rest or nap.
We were a group of 7 seniors and we hit different destinations. We came home tired but loving our trip and Everything we saw.
I agree 100%. We spent 3-4 nights in each city and we were traveling for 26 days. We found the train travel very relaxing and it was a little down time from the sightseeing. It was perfect!
Good point! One has to know their travel style. We rather savor than rush, but that’s not for everyone.

If you are happy & had a wonderful time. That is all that matters. I personally like to do more in some of those cities. I haven’t made it Rome yet. Honestly. I would do 7-9 days myself. Florence I did but would do 5 days….most being day trips to other cities. Venice-3 days. 4 if you go to Verona.

Sounds perfect! I wish we would have planned multiple nights each place we were…packing up stuff many nights in a row got to be a bit tiresome to me…but I treasure every moment! Absolutely fell in love with Italy and the people!
💯 similar experience and it was awesome 🤩

Just be sure to factor in time and stress for all location changes: pack & hotel check out, transport to rail station, wait for train, train ride to next location, arrival/ disembark at new location, transport to new hotel, check in at new hotel and get settled in room, gain situational awareness and develop exploration plan …… . Yes, experienced travelers can do it all in stride, but most travelers should factor in at least half a travel day (sometimes more). Be prepared for your room not being ready and you having to either wait or leave your bags and come back later.
Good for you 😊

Thanks for this post. We're going to Italy/
Switzerland in Sep and we're staying only 2-3 nights in places. This is also how we like to travel. We never like to stay more than 3 nights anywhere we go. I'm very excited about our itinerary. I just see the train trips as some rest time, because otherwise we never sit still!
Can you share the Switzerland part of the trip? How did you get there? Was it a tour or did you do it by yourself? Please and thank you!

text: Ladies! We are preparing for a 3 week Italian adventure. I understand that Italy is hot this time of year and don’t want to overpack for cooler “what if’s” if I can avoid it! https://
store.ricksteves
.com/shop/p/

Just got back yesterday from a 14 day trip. 💯 liquid IV. All 3 of us managed with a carry on luggage and carry bag/backpack and we still overpacked. Good white sneakers and Birkenstocks. Never touched my pants shorts, wore my long tank/maxi dress once and was very overheated. Two thin tshirts for sleeping. Light undies and bras easily washed and hung to dry by morning. text:
Any preference on trains in Italy?
Ítalo, Frecciarossa, Trenord, Intercity, etc.

comments.comment_text: F

Italo and Frecciarossa are the fast train connecting the main cities, i prefeir Frecciarossa but are almost the same.
Frecciabianca/
Frecciargento are a little slower and connecting the minor cities.
Intercity and Trenord are going almost everywhere but are the slowest and the service Is not very good on some routes.

The majority of the trains are run by the state company Trenitalia, of which Frecciarossa is a subsidiary. Two exceptions are Italo, wich sorely operates on the high speed lines, and Trenord wich is only partially public.
If it's available for your route you should always book Frecciarossa or Italo trains.
If you go on the Trenitalia website (https://
www.trenitalia.c
om/) you will be able to buy a ticket a reserve a seat for all the routes in Italy.
Otherwise, go for Italo https://
biglietti.italot
reno.it/

Let's try to make this clear.
Companies: trenitalia, NTV, trenord.
NTV only provides for high speed trains (italo).
Trenord only manages regional trains in the northern regions
Trenitalia provides for both high speed (frecciarossa, frecciargento),
intermediate speed (frecciabianca,
intercity) and regional trains.
Freccia!
Italio

Italy (as well as the rest of Europe) uses higher voltage AND has wall outlets that require different shaped plugs. You need to worry about both if you are taking electric appliances there. Be aware that the terminology used online is often inconsistent and confusing.
Many electronics like phones, iPads and laptops are already dual voltage (check the label on the back, it should say something like 110 - 240 V). For these, you only need an adaptor which “adapts” the plug to the shape of the wall outlet.
If your appliance is not dual voltage, you will need both an adaptor and a converter. A converter “converts” the voltage coming from the wall (220V) to the voltage (120V) needed by your appliance. If you don’t use a converter, you will trip a breaker, burn up your appliance and/or start a fire.
The problem for travelers is that most appliances with motors or that heat need a lot of power (watts), and the converters needed are very heavy.
The best thing to do is buy a dual voltage appliance and then only an adaptor (specific to country or area) is needed wherever you travel.
Another option would be to buy a 220V version in Europe.
If, however, you want to try a converter, check that label again for the wattage and make sure that the converter is adequate for the wattage of your appliance.

text: I am curious about the Trevi fountain. The overhead photos look like the building attached on the back side looks like the building goes on for blocks. What is in the rest of that building.thanks

comments.comment_text:
The Palazzo Poli is a palace in Rome, Italy, that was altered in the 18th century to form the backdrop to the Trevi Fountain. In the 1830s, Princess Zinaida Volkonskaya threw lavish parties in this palace.
Maria Cristina Misiti, director of the National Institute of Graphics, had the idea to turn the building into a museum to help visitors learn more about the history of Rome and its inhabitants. The Palazzo Poli houses the Institute's collection of copper engraving plates dated from the sixteenth century to the present
Just an FYI, you can tour the inner workings of the fountain. Most people don't know this but a tour is available for those interested.
We saw this in April, we just walked in. I think it was 7 or 11 euros
